description:
Paraphaeosphaeria sporulosa is a species of fungus belonging to the phylum Ascomycota. It is a saprobic fungus, meaning it feeds on decaying organic matter, and is commonly found on dead plant material such as leaves, stems, and twigs.

The fungus produces small, black, flask-shaped fruiting bodies called perithecia, which are typically less than 0.5 millimeters in diameter. These perithecia contain numerous asci, which are the reproductive structures that produce ascospores. The ascospores are single-celled, elliptical, and hyaline (colorless) in appearance.

Paraphaeosphaeria sporulosa is known to exhibit a characteristic feature called sporulation, where it can produce abundant small, dark-colored spores called conidia on the surface of the fruiting bodies. These conidia serve as an additional means of dispersal and propagation for the fungus.

The taxonomy of Paraphaeosphaeria sporulosa is as follows: Kingdom Fungi, Phylum Ascomycota, Class Dothideomycetes, Order Pleosporales, Family Paraphaeosphaeriaceae, Genus Paraphaeosphaeria, Species sporulosa.
